title: Former Thomas Cook boss squirms as he's urged to repay millions in bonuses
text:

Former Thomas Cook chief executive Peter Fankhauser squirmed as MPs urged him to repay his bonuses.

Peter Fankhauser told MPs he is "deeply sorry" he failed to save the company but he looked uncomfortable as the chair of the business committee suggested he should personally cough up.

Thomas Cook collapsed after failing to secure an extra £200m needed to keep it afloat.

Mr Fankhauser has previously said half of the £8.3million package he got since 2014 came is now worthless shares in the travel giant.

Meanwhile some 6,000 of the travel giant's 9,000 UK staff were not paid their month’s wages due at the end of last month.

Kicking off the grilling of the fat cat boss, Chair Rachel Reeves said: "Your apologies would perhaps ring a bit more true if you were willing to do something about it."

She told the former CEO: "At the moment "I'm afraid Mr Frankhauser the number of times you've said 'sorry' when you're not willing to put something back."

"I will reflect on that chair and decide what is right but I'm not going to decide that today."

(Image: PA)

Asked about his pay Mr Fankhauser said: "I'm not going to try and defend my base pay because in relation to a normal worker's base salary this is a normal amount."

But he insisted that he "worked extremely hard and exhaustively hard" for the money.

He told MPs: "I didn't get a bonus for 2018 or 2019 of course and half of my total compensation which was in the press was paid in shares and either that was 30% of the bonuses were paid in shares and about one long term incentive plan paid out in 2015 so £4m of value it was in shares.

He insisted: "My commitment to the company was shown by I never sold one share because I was believing in the company I was believing in the success of the company and this is what I have to say about my salary."

Mr Fankhauser last received a bonus in 2017 when he was handed £750,000 of which 30% was in shares.

(Image: PA)

Asked if any of the cash money could be clawed back, he replied: "I honestly was not thinking about that because I'm not the one who was setting my pay and I'm not the one who is deciding my bonus.

Mr Fankhauser is one of five senior Thomas Cook figures giving evidence to the Commons' Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee.

He told MPs: "I fully understand where you are coming from and I fully understand the sentiment in the public I fully understand the sentiment of some of our colleagues, however, what I can say to that is that I worked tirelessly for the success of this company and I'm deeply sorry that I was not able to secure the deal but it was not one hand sided that I failed it there were multiple parties who had to contribute to the deal which then finally didn't succeed."
description: Peter Fankhauser told MPs he is "deeply sorry" he failed to save the company
